text: JPMORGAN CHASE & CO.
October 13, 2023
ROTCE was 22%.
CET1 capital ratios were 14.3% Standard and 14.5% Advanced.
Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity was $496B.
Standardized RWA was $1.7T.
Cash and marketable securities totaled $1.4T.
Average loans were $1.3T.
3Q23 net income was $13.2B and EPS was $4.33.
Managed revenue was $40.7B and the managed overhead ratio was 53%.
Average loans of $1.3T were up 17% YoY and 5% QoQ. Excluding First Republic (FR), average loans were $1.2T, up 4% YoY and 2% QoQ.
Average deposits of $2.4T were down 4% YoY and 1% QoQ. Excluding FR, average deposits were $2.3T, down 6% YoY and 2% QoQ.
CET1 capital was $242B, with a standardized CET1 capital ratio of 14.3% and an advanced CET1 capital ratio of 14.5%.
Distributed $3.1B in common dividends, or $1.05 per share.
Completed $2.0B of common stock net repurchases.
Net payout for the last twelve months was 35%.
3Q23 Tax rate: Effective rate: 21.4%, Managed rate: 25.0%.
CCB 3Q23 metrics: ROE 41%, O/H ratio 50%.
CIB 3Q23 metrics: ROE 11%, O/H ratio 63%.
CB 3Q23 metrics: ROE 25%, O/H ratio 34%.
AWM 3Q23 metrics: ROE 32%, O/H ratio 63%.
As proposed, the U.S. B3E NPR increases the Firm's RWA by 30% ($500B) and required capital by 25% ($50B).
$22.5B of the increase is directly linked to the firm's 4.5% GSIB surcharge (4.5% x $500B), despite no change in the systemic risk footprint.
The proposal increases the required capital for operational risk by $30B.
The firm estimates its SCB already includes ~$15B capital for operational risk.
JPM believes that an RWA change of this magnitude requires corresponding adjustments to SCB and GSIB.
Measured since the 2017 rules, JPM's CET1 capital requirements will have increased by ~45% should the rule be enacted as proposed.
Looking beyond the B3E proposal, the future trend for capital requirements is upward.
The firm anticipates that the Fed's incorporation of CECL in the stress test will raise the SCB.
Since the GSIB proposal did not adjust for growth, continued headwinds are expected due to ordinary economic growth.
JPM disagrees with the cost-benefit analysis and believes that increases of this magnitude are unwarranted.
Excluding FR, net income was $5.3B, up 22% YoY.
Excluding FR, revenue was $17.0B, up 19% YoY, driven by higher net interest income.
Excluding FR, expense was $8.5B, up 7% YoY, driven by higher compensation, technology and marketing investments, and the FDIC assessment increase, partially offset by lower auto lease depreciation.
Excluding FR, credit costs were $1.4B, with NCOs of $1.4B, up $720mm YoY, driven by normalization in Card Services.
Excluding FR, a net reserve build of $49mm reflected a $301mm build in Card Services, offset by a $250mm release in Home Lending.
Excluding FR, average loans were up 6% YoY and 3% QoQ.
Excluding FR, average deposits were down 8% YoY and 3% QoQ.
Excluding FR, active mobile customers were up 9% YoY.
Excluding FR, debit & credit card sales volume was up 8% YoY.
Excluding FR, client investment assets were up 21% YoY and flat QoQ.
Net income was $3.1B, down 12% YoY; revenue was $11.7B, down 2% YoY.
IB revenue was $1.6B, down 6% YoY, with IB fees down 3% YoY.
Payments revenue was $2.1B, up 3% YoY.
Lending revenue was $291mm, down 10% YoY.
Markets & Securities Services revenue includes Markets revenue of $6.6B (down 3% YoY) and Securities Services revenue of $1.2B (up 9% YoY).
Fixed Income Markets revenue was $4.5B, up 1% YoY.
Equity Markets revenue was $2.1B, down 10% YoY.
Expense of $7.4B was up 11% YoY, driven by higher legal expense and wage inflation.
Credit costs were a net benefit of $185mm, including a net reserve release of $230mm and NCOs of $45mm.
Excluding FR impact, Net income was $1.7B, up 79% YoY.
Excluding FR impact, Revenue was $3.7B, up 20% YoY, with Payments revenue up 30% YoY and Investment Banking and Markets revenue up 8% YoY.
Excluding FR impact, Expense was $1.4B, up 15% YoY, driven by increased headcount and volume-related expenses.
Excluding FR impact, Credit costs were $64mm, including NCOs of $50mm and a reserve build of $14mm.
Excluding FR impact, Average loans were $244B, up 6% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Excluding FR impact, Average deposits were $262B, down 7% YoY and 5% QoQ.
Excluding FR impact, net income was $1.1B, down 12% YoY.
Excluding FR impact, revenue of $4.6B was relatively flat YoY, driven by higher management fees offset by lower performance fees and net interest income.
Excluding FR impact, expense of $3.1B was up 3% YoY, driven by growth in private banking advisor teams and other impacts.
AUM of $3.2T was up 22% YoY and client assets of $4.6T were up 21% YoY, driven by net inflows and higher market levels.
For the quarter, AUM had long-term net inflows of $20B and liquidity net inflows of $40B.
Excluding FR impact, average loans of $211B were down 3% YoY and flat QoQ.
Excluding FR impact, average deposits of $202B were down 20% YoY and down 5% QoQ.
Excluding FR impact, revenue was $1.5B, an increase of $1.8B YoY.
Excluding FR impact, Net interest income was $2.0B, compared with $792mm in the prior year, driven by higher rates.
Excluding FR impact, Noninterest revenue was a loss of $506mm, compared with a loss of $1.1B in the prior year, and included $669mm of net investment securities losses.
Excluding FR impact, expense of $456mm was up $151mm YoY.
Expect FY2023 net interest income of ~$88.5B, market dependent.
Expect FY2023 net interest income excluding Markets of ~$89B, market dependent.
Expect FY2023 adjusted expense of ~$84B excluding the FDIC special assessment related to systemic risk determination, market dependent.
Adjusted expense excludes Firmwide legal expense ($1.3B year-to-date).
Expect FY2023 Card Services NCO rate of ~2.50%.
Management reviews Firmwide results on a 'managed' basis, a non-GAAP measure which reclassifies revenue from tax-exempt sources to a fully taxable-equivalent basis to allow for better comparability.

Management also reviews net interest income (NII) and noninterest revenue (NIR) excluding CIB Markets to assess the performance of lending, investing, and deposit-raising activities separately from market volatility.
Tangible common equity (TCE), return on tangible common equity (ROTCE), and tangible book value per share (TBVPS) are non-GAAP measures used to assess the Firm's use of equity.
Adjusted expense and adjusted overhead ratio are non-GAAP measures that exclude certain items like Firmwide legal expense to help investors understand underlying performance.
CET1 capital figures reflect the Current Expected Credit Losses (CECL) capital transition provisions, with a remaining benefit of $1.4B as of September 30, 2023.
Total excess high-quality liquid assets (HQLA) represents the average eligible unencumbered liquid assets in excess of what is required under the LCR rule.
In 1Q23, revenue and expense allocations to CCB from a Merchant Services agreement were discontinued and are now retained in Payments in CIB; prior periods were revised for conformity.
The 3Q22 prior-period amount for HQLA has been revised to use end-of-period figures to conform with the current presentation.
Slide 4 footnotes provide definitions for B3E NPR, GSIB, and details on calculations for operational risk losses and SCB.
Slide 5 footnotes detail the assumptions behind the '19%' capital increase, including a flat balance sheet and the impacts of SA-CCR and the GSIB NPR.
Slide 6 footnotes clarify that metrics for Consumer & Community Banking are actual numbers (not over/under), define mobile users, and specify exclusions like First Republic and Commercial Card.
Slide 7 footnotes for Corporate & Investment Bank clarify that metrics are actual numbers and define the scope of client deposits and merchant processing volume.
Metrics for Commercial Banking are actual numbers for all periods, not over/(under).
In 3Q23, certain revenue from CIB Markets products was reclassified from payments to investment banking.
Gross revenues include those from a revenue sharing arrangement between CB and CIB.
The impact of loans originated under the PPP is included.
Loans held-for-sale and at fair value were excluded when calculating the net charge-off/(recovery) rate.
C&I and CRE groupings for CB are based on client segments and may not align with regulatory definitions.
